literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Actor
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Bruno Latour ... any thing that does modify a state of affairs by making a difference is an actor ... (Latour, 2005)p.71).
Terms actor and actant both refer to entities with the capacity to act. The "actant/actor" are used sometimes interchangeably, but the distinction can also be a key tool in ANT for analyzing the unfolding of agency (Matozzi, 2019)p.94). These entities participating in the action are not strictly (intentional) humans, but extends to include the "nonhumans", i.e. anything that makes a difference (Latour, 2005)p.71-72).
Crucially for ANT, the term actor in "actor-network" is intentionally oxymoronic, embodying the tension between a centered "actor" and a decentered "network", thus eliding the distinction between "agency" and "structure" (Law, 1999)p.5). A defining aspect for both of them in ANT is that they make a difference. If an entity makes no difference, it is not considered an actor but a passive intermediary. An actor is thus what is not entirely substitutable. (Latour, 2005)p.130;153.)
"Actant" is often used when the entity does not yet have a specific figuration or identity beyond its capacity to act (Latour, 2005)p.71). Generally, it is used to point to "anything that acts" regardless of its ontological status, size, scale, or features, providing a descriptive term for the principle of symmetry (Matozzi, 2019)p.94). Actant is then a slightly broader term than actor, and often used in a more general and symmetrical way to include anything that participates in a network and influences outcomes, particularly before a stable identity or figuration is established.
"Actor" can then denote an actant with more specific features, relationships, and a recognized role within the network. Actor can be understood as an actant that possesses additional features and engages in various relations beyond simply performing an action. While anything that acts is an actant, what acts is not reducible solely to the performed action. For example (Akrich & Latour, 1992), a written note and a weight can both function as the same actant by reminding a hotel guest to return the key. However, in the given example they are different actors with distinct physical characteristics and may contribute differently to the hotel manager's goals.
Figuration gives actants "flesh and features that make them have some form or shape, no matter how vague". These are not limited to anthropomorphic forms; they can also be e.g. ideo- or technomorphic. An actor is an actant that has been given a specific figuration. In ANT process, the analysis often involves moving from the identification of actants to the figuration of actors with more defined roles and attributes within a network. Therefore, the figuration that distinguishes the actor from the actant is one that endows the actant with specific characteristics, attributes agency to it, or positions it within a network in a defined way, moving beyond the basic definition of "anything that acts". (Latour, 2005)p.53-55.)
ANT treats actors symmetrically by employing a methodological principle known as generalized symmetry. This principle suggests that when studying a situation or a network, researchers should remain agnostic regarding what counts as an actor and should not a priori assume that humans and nonhumans have fundamentally different types of agency or causal power. (Law, 2004)p.101-103;(Callon, 1986)p.201.)
ANT also proposes that agency is not an inherent property of individual actors (whether human or nonhuman) but rather an emergent effect of the relationships and associations within a network (Nimmo, 2011)p.112). Actors are seen as "network effects" because they do not possess inherent, fixed properties or agency in isolation. Instead, their characteristics, capabilities, and even their very existence are consequences of the relationships and connections they form and maintain within a heterogeneous network of other actors/actants - human and nonhuman. (Law & Hassard, 1999);(Law, 1999).
Bruno Latour ANT is not the empty claim that objects do things âinsteadâ of human actors ... It does not designate little goblins with red hats acting at atomic levels, only that the analyst should be prepared to look in order to account for the durability and extension of any interaction. (Latour, 2005)p.72.)

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Actor-Network
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
An actor-network is the structure and operation of an actor-world, that is an interrelated set of entities that have been successfully translated or enrolled. These entities are actors; heterogeneous, composed of animate and inanimate, human and nonhuman elements linked together for a period. It is reducible neither to an actor alone nor to a network alone, because an actor-network is simultaneously an actor whose activity is networking heterogeneous elements and a network that is able to redefine and transform what it is made of. (Callon et al., 1986);(Callon, 1987)
Agency, power, social order, organizations, and devices are seen as effects generated in or by these heterogeneous networks of human and nonhuman elements (Law, 1992). Ultimately, a network in ANT is not a static thing, but rather the recorded movement of a thing. It is a concept or tool used for description, not the thing being described (Latour, 2005)p.131). The actor-network then serves as a concept or a tool for describing how social phenomena are assembled and ordered.
ANT challenges the concepts of Euclideanism and regionalism, which assume the world is a surface or volume divisible into principalities. It argues that entities and materials do not exist within a conformable three-dimensional space or in fixed geographical areas. ANT proposes a change in topology where entities are understood as nodes that possess as many dimensions as they have connections. In this alternative topological system, elements retain their spatial integrity by virtue of their position within a set of links or relations, rather than their volume. (Law, 1999).
ANT's topology is thus non-Euclidean. Inspired by Deleuze's "rhizomes", (Latour, 1996) suggests that modern societies possess a "fibrous, thread-like, wiry, stringy, ropy, capillary character" that cannot be captured by traditional notions of structure, layers, territories, spheres or categories. ANT aims to "reshuffle spatial metaphors" such as close and far, up and down, local and global, replacing them with associations and connections (ibid.). This results in a ontologically "flattened landscape" where the former global and local sites take on a "star-shaped aspect," existing side-by-side rather than hierarchically ordered within a three-dimensional structure (Latour, 2005)p.212-213).
From this perspective, ANT posits that there is "nothing but networks" and no "aether" in which networks should be immersed, thus the focus is on connections and transformations rather than fixed substances or structures (Latour, 1996)(Latour, 2005)p.107). A consequence of this non-Euclidean perspective is ANT's critique of analyses that assume pre-given distinctions between micro- and macro-scales. It does not deny them as effects (Latour, 1996)p.372) but instead, it advocates for an "analytics of scale making," where size and power are understood as outcomes of dynamic translation processes rather than inherent properties. (Callon et al., 1986)p.228.)

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Actor-Network Theory
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
John Law ... an approach to sociotechnical analysis that treats entities and materialities as enacted and relational effects, and explores the configuration and reconfiguration of those relations (Law, 2004)p.157).
Actor-Network Theory (ANT, fin. toimijaverkkoteoria) is often described as an approach, sensibility, program or orientation to relationality, materiality, heterogeneity and process for sociotechnical or -material analysis (Law, 2004)p.157);(Latour, 1999). It aims for empirical descriptions of the relational ties and sociomaterial flux and it's translations in a network (Latour, 2005). The unit of analysis is often process (Miettinen, 1999)p.174). Despite its name, whether it truly is a theory is debatable and there is even an a-theoretical nature to it (Latour, 2005).
ANT has its roots in the Centre de Sociologie de l'Innovation (CSI) of the Mines de Paris and emerged from the field of Science and Technology Studies (STS) in the early 1980s. It was/is often referred also to as "a sociology of translations" or "a sociology of associations" before the term Actor-Network Theory was coined. (Akrich, 2023);(Callon, 2001). Foundational scholars are considered to be Bruno Latour, Madeleine Akrich, John Law and Michel Callon. Other influential, but not at all peripheral, are e.g. Annemarie Mol, Steve Woolgar, Karin Knorr-Cetina and Donna Haraway. In the context of Innovation Systems, has Reijo Miettinen examined the applicability of ANT since the 1990s. As previously stated, it is well used, developed and debated in social sciences, but has been "spread" over various other fields and uses (Law, 1999)p.10).
In the field of Innovation Management have (Sieklicki & Tanev, 2021) recognized in their review three somewhat different literature streams of actor-network theory: descriptive, proactive managerial and proactive collaborative. The descriptive stream stays strictly symmetrical, where the latter two somewhat break the symmetry in order to enable actionable insights.
ANT has evolved through the decades and because it lacks a theoretical unity it might be difficult to define (Miettinen, 1999)p.171). There is no generic way to apply ANT because there is no clear "methodological prescription", but there are many key elements and choices that persist in it's intellectual practice (Jackson, 2015) or show up in contemporary ANT "and After".
Key concepts, after (Jackson, 2015);(Walsham, 1997): Core concepts:
Actor
Actor-Network
Generalized Symmetry
(Ontological) Agnosticism
Heterogeneity Hybridity
Multiplicity Network dynamics:
Translation
Inscription (Device)
Intermediaries and Mediators
Punctualisation (Black Box)
Immutable Mobile and Object
Obligatory Passage Point Quasi-Object Methodological considerations: Reflexivity
Controversies
Method Assemblage From these key concepts we can conceive the following ordering:Note Actor-Network Theory views reality as constructed through dynamic networks of diverse actors, both human and nonhuman, treating them with generalized symmetry and ontological agnosticism. These actor-networks, characterized by heterogeneity and hybridity, are enacted through processes of translation, where e.g. inscriptions and quasi-objects facilitate interactions via intermediaries and mediators. Through enrolment, actants are integrated, and often networks have obligatory passage points where all actors must converge. Immutable mobiles and objects stabilize and disseminate influence, revealing the multiplicity inherent in social and material realities. Complex networks are often simplified into punctualised black boxes, which the ANT tries to provide a view into.
ANT does not use "society" or "social" as explanations in its analysis, but instead tries to explain them "in the making" as an ongoing achievement. It aims not to reproduce the classical oppositions or dualisms of nature/culture, micro/macro, agency/culture etc. or to see facts mirroring nature, but to show how they are constructed and to provide tools for analyzing that process. (Callon, 2001). It is thus a constructionist, post-structuralist, material-semiotic and an anti-essentialist approach. In the context of innovation processes, ANT is commonly used to study them as a simultaneous development of an artefact and a network of actors connected to it (Miettinen, 1999)p.170). ... ANT and After; Near ANT; methodology
Methodological principles (Latour, 2005);(Law, 2004);(Bignetti et al., 2023) Follow the actors Radical empiricism No pre-defined social Focus on associations Translation, not diffusion Description, not explanation first Symmetry principle Non-Euclideanity
In many ways a similar approach called the Social Construction of Technology (SCOT, foundational authors being Wiebe Bijker & Trevor Pinch) can not be accounted as ANT, according to (Latour, 2005)p. 10-11), since in it the "the social is kept stable all along and accounts for the shape of technological change." Another similarly kept approach is the Cultural Historical Activity Theory (AT or CHAT), which has a different disciplinary and philosophical background, but shares many methodological grounds (Miettinen, 1999). A closely related and broader body of thought is New Materialism, which it shares with e.g. the "flat" ontology and in some sense ANT (and perhaps also AT) can be seen as a contribution to it (Kamp, 2019).
Although ANT is historically based in the sociology of science and technology, according to (Miettinen, 1999)p.181) the ANT task for innovation processes "seems hopeless". ... ...

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Generalized Symmetry
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Generalized symmetry is a central methodological principle, that functions as a strategy to adopt an agnostic stance regarding what qualifies as an actor in a specific context. This principle advocates also for the symmetrical treatment of both human and nonhuman entities as a priori equals within the analysis. (FarÃ­as et al., 2020)p.xxi);(Callon, 1986);(Latour, 1999). The primary aim of generalized symmetry is to avoid pre-determined assumptions about the nature of actors, resisting the urge to impose a priori distinctions between human intentional action and a material world of causal relations.
John Law To say that there is no fundamental difference between people and objects is an analytical stance, not an ethical position (Law, 1992)p.4).
This demands that analyst refrains from changing their analytical framework when moving between the "technical/natural" and the social aspects of a study. This also means using the same vocabulary or "repertoire" to describe the actions and roles of the actors. (Callon, 1986)p.200;221-222.) This does not mean a imperative to treat humans and nonhumans identically in all respects, but rather it suggests that the divisions between them are outcomes of processes, not pre-existing conditions. It serves as a "heuristic flattening" to better understand how diverse elements work together. (Jackson, 2015)p.38-39);(Law, 1999).
The objective is to look beyond traditional human-centric perspectives and explore web of relationships involving a diverse array of actants (both human and nonhuman) in the construction of realities. It prompts an analysis that gives due consideration to the agency and contribution of all elements within a network without initial (often hierarchical) assumption.

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Heterogeneity
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
The general description of heterogeneity signals something consisting of dissimilar, diverse or different elements (Merriam-Webster, n.d.). In actor-network theory the concept emphasizes the study of how diverse elements, both human and nonhuman, are interconnected and contribute to the formation of networks, referring to the recognition of the world as composed of a multiplicity of different kinds of connections, entities and realities (Latour, 2005);(Law, 2004). In understanding this notion the principle of generalized symmetry is crucial.
ANT posits that actors and their networks are fundamentally heterogeneous, composed of a mix of human and nonhuman elements without a specific homogeneous morphism or other purity-seeking classification as a rule (Latour, 1996)p.370;380).

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Inscription
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description: Inscription, as in (Latour & Woolgar, 1986) borrowed from Derrida, refers to a broad range of outputs, traces, marks, symbols, and written or graphic accounts that summarize or embody information about the world. It is considered an operation more fundamental than simple writing; instead "revealing" the "true" representation of the world, the (scientific) knowledge is made real through inscription devices and practices. Inscriptions are material things, and they can be found in various forms such as written words, histograms, spreadsheets, spectra, memos, journals and books (Callon et al., 1986)p.10-11.) A core insight is that phenomena, things and realities are thoroughly constituted by the material settings and specifically by inscription devices, which then are not merely tools to observe an independently existing reality; rather, they construct that reality (Latour & Woolgar, 1986).Material-semiotics Network-tracing Immutable mobiles ...

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Intermediaries and Mediators
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description: Bruno Latour An intermediary, in my vocabulary, is what transports meaning or force without transformation: defining its inputs is enough to define its outputs. For all practical purposes, an intermediary can be taken not only as a black box, but also as a black box counting for one, even if it is internally made of many parts. Mediators, on the other hand, cannot be counted as just one; they might count for one, for nothing, for several, or for infinity. Their input is never a good predictor of their output; their specificity has to be taken into account every time. (Latour, 2005)p.39).
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.sourcePath: Literature Survey/Framework/ANT and After/Intermediaries and Mediators.md

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Obligatory Passage Point
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
An obligatory passage point (OPP) describes a position within a network through which other actors must pass to achieve their goal. An OPP can be envisioned as a specific point or node within a network of interconnected actors, where their "threads" converge and pass through. (Callon, 1986)p.205-206.)
The concept of OPP also describes the establishment and evolution of power relationships within a network. The actor who controls an OPP holds a position of influence because other actors are dependent on passing through it to further their own interests. The ability of one actor to lock other actors into passing through an OPP is a stage of interessement in the process of translation. (Watson, 2007)p.11-12);(Callon, 1986)p.205-211.)
Example Researchers in (Callon, 1986) attempt to establish their research program as an OPP, arguing that the interests of scallops, scientific colleagues, and fishermen depend on admitting this program.
A successful OPP can often become punctualised into a black box. When an actor, set of elements or even the actor-network itself successfully establishes itself as an indispensable point through which others must pass (an OPP), the need to scrutinize its internal complexities and the network that sustains it diminishes. It becomes a stable, unquestioned entity â a black box. (Latour, 1987)p.139.)
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.sourcePath: Literature Survey/Framework/ANT and After/Obligatory Passage Point.md

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Punctualisation
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Punctualisation refers to the simplificatory effects when network patterns are widely performed and can be more or less taken for granted (Law, 1992)p.5). These punctualised networks are sometimes referred to by some as black boxes. The word is borrowed from cybernetics, where for example a piece of machinery or software becomes too complex to describe, so it's reduced to a "box in the chart" with inputs and outputs (Latour, 1987)p.2-3).
When everything goes well, it can appear as if black boxes are effortlessly moving through space, durable by their own inner strength, leading to illusions of "irreversible progress of science" or "irresistible power of technology" - inertia (Latour, 1987)p.132). This represents "ready-made science" or technology, often described in terms of diffusion.
However, this appearance masks the labor involved in building and maintaining the network, so black boxes are more like "lashups of heterogeneous bits and pieces" (Law, 1999)p.216-217). Their stability is not written in the stone either, they face resistance and may as well fail (Law, 1992)p.5).
A successful black box acts also as an obligatory passage point, holding together different systems of alliances (Latour, 1987)p.139):
Bruno Latour This is why we call such black boxes 'hard facts', or 'highly sophisticated machines', or 'powerful theories', or 'indisputable evidence'. All these adjectives that allude to strength and power rightly point out the disproportionate number of associations gathered in these black boxes, so disproportionate indeed that they are what keep the multitude of allies in place. (Latour, 1987)p.139).

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Translation
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Michel Callon Translation is the mechanism by which the social and natural worlds progressively take form (Callon, 1986)p.224).
Michel Callon This methodological choice through which society is rendered as uncertain and disputable as nature, reveals an unusual reality which is accounted for quite faithfully by the vocabulary of translation (Callon, 1986)p.222).
Rather than viewing the social as a separate domain, ANT sees it as an effect of heterogeneous associations (Latour, 2005). Within ANT, the concept of translation is central to understanding how these associations are formed and maintained. Developed by Michel Serres and then articulated by Michel Callon, translation emphasizes the continuity of displacements and transformations that occur within a project, story, case etc. - a process (Callon, 1986).
Four Moments of Translation, after (Callon, 1986) 1. Problematization
Initial attempt by an actor to define a problem and to position other actors in relation to it. 2. Interessement Attempts to persuade other actors to accept the definitions and roles proposed in the problematization. 3. Enrolment Actors negotiate and define their roles within the network, establishing stable relationships. 4. Mobilization Ensuring that designated spokespersons effectively represent their constituencies.
Initially the semiotic relations were "left open", but contemporarily ANT highlights how links are made between different entities, focusing on the work of making two things that are not the same, equivalent (Law, 1999)p.8). So it is not just a linguistic phenomenon but also a semiotic operation involving the displacement of logical relations between seemingly opposed sets of significations, interests, and concerns (Callon, 1980)p.211);(Brown & Capdevila, 1999)p.32).
Within this process of translation, the identification of obligatory passage points (OPP) plays a crucial role. They are specific "points" in this program through which the interests of all involved actors must pass to be satisfied. (Callon, 1986)p.205-206.) Somewhat related concept discussed e.g. by (Latour & Woolgar, 1986) is "black-boxing" or punctualisation, where the successful translation leads to the network being represented and treated as a single, coherent entity - as a black box.
The diffusion model is a way of understanding how facts, artefacts etc. spread in time and space, that ANT critiques as being overly simplistic. The diffusion model suggests that once a fact or artifact is established, people easily agree to transmit it, as if the object itself forces their assent. This model often invents a form of technological determinism, where innovations seem to spread with their own inherent strength, irresistibly imposing themselves, as if having their own vis inertia and explaining non-adoption as mere "resistance". Contrarily, innovation seen through translation (Model of Interessement) emphasizes that an innovation's journey involves active work in shaping and building a network of heterogenous relationships. The interests of different actors (human and nonhuman) are negotiated and potentially transformed in relation to the innovation, an the innovation itself may very well be transformed as it moves through different contexts and encounters different actors. (Latour, 1987)p.132-144.)

literature-survey/framework/other/activi.title: Activity Theory
literature-survey/framework/other/activi.description: Activity Theory (AT) is a theoretical framework that approaches the study of technical innovations by aiming to transcend the dualism between subject and object, and between nature and society. It posits that human activity is mediated by artefacts, which can include tools, signs, and representations. These artifacts play a crucial role in structuring activity and influencing human behavior. Activity Theory is sometimes compared with Actor-Network Theory due to their shared attempt to transcend subject-object dualisms. While ANT may emphasize generalized symmetry between human and non-human entities, AT focuses on the mediated structure of human activity and its socio-cultural context. @miettinenRiddleThingsActivity1999.

literature-survey/framework/philosophy/o.title: Ontology
literature-survey/framework/philosophy/o.description:
ANT emphasizes a relational ontology, where reality is not assumed as given but arises from the practices, relationships, and effects of various actors (human and nonhuman) that associate and dissociate in different arrangements.

literature-survey/methodology/digital-ga.title: Digital Garden
literature-survey/methodology/digital-ga.description:
#partiallyAIgenerated Examples
Discrete Structures for Computer Science On discrete mathematics for computer science majors, by R. Talbert.
Nokia Design Archive Interactive portal for Aalto University's project (Valtonen, Julier, Savola et. al.)
A Pattern Language Digitized C. Alexander's 1977 book on architecture, urban design and communities.
Scaling Synthesis A "living hypertext notebook" for a research project. A digital garden is a metaphor for an online space where thoughts, ideas, and notes are cultivated and interconnected over time. In online space it's distinct e.g. from a traditional blog in several key ways. Unlike many types of texts, which are typically published and then left as static pieces, digital garden entries are meant to be living documents that are constantly updated, revised, and expanded upon. The focus is on the process of developing ideas, rather than presenting finished products.
Digital gardens often utilize extensive internal linking to create a network of interconnected ideas. This somewhat resembles the idea of pattern language and allows readers to explore related concepts and follow the evolution of the author's thinking. This linking creates a non linear way of navigating the information. Digital gardens are often highly personal spaces where individuals can explore their own interests and develop their own unique perspectives. It is a place for the author to cultivate their own thoughts.In essence, a digital garden is a space for continuous learning, reflection, and connection, where ideas are nurtured and allowed to grow organically.

literature-survey/methodology/pattern-la.title: Pattern Language
literature-survey/methodology/pattern-la.description:
#partiallyAIgenerated
The concept of pattern language was popularized by architect Christopher Alexander and his colleagues in their book, "A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction" @alexanderPatternLanguageTowns1977. While originating in architecture, the concept of pattern languages has been applied to other fields, including software engineering, where "design patterns" are used to document and share best practices. The concept isn't applied or practiced in this project, but its philosophy is adjacent to the Digital Garden you're currently reading at. See also the Wikipedia articleEssentially, a pattern language is: A System of Solutions: It's an organized set of "patterns," where each pattern describes a recurring problem and offers a core solution that can be adapted to various contexts. Design Guidance: It provides a framework for designing and building environments, from entire towns to individual rooms, in a way that promotes human well-being and a sense of place. Interconnected Patterns: The patterns are interconnected, forming a "language" that allows designers and builders to create cohesive and harmonious environments. Focus on Human Experience: The patterns are rooted in observations of how people interact with their surroundings and aim to create spaces that support positive human experiences. Key aspects of a pattern language include: Patterns as Problem-Solution Pairs: Each pattern consists of a description of a common problem, followed by a proposed solution. Contextual Solutions: The solutions are not rigid formulas but rather guidelines that can be adapted to specific contexts and needs. Hierarchical Structure: The patterns are organized in a hierarchical structure, ranging from large-scale patterns (e.g., urban planning) to small-scale patterns (e.g., room details).

research-plan/research-plan.html.title: Research Plan
research-plan/research-plan.html.description:
Last updated 7.3.2025 Info Janne W. Matilainen (janne.matilainen@lapinamk.fi) University of Lapland - Faculty of Social Sciences Lapland University of Applied Sciences - Smart Built Environment Research field: Social Sciences - Management/Organization Studies Keywords (YSO): actor-network theory, innovation system, innovation policy, regions, research and development operations, university of applied science The Universities of Applied Sciences (UAS) in Finland have an applied and regional role in the Finnish innovation systems. Their research, development and innovation (RDI) activities are changing, gaining maturity and beginning to find their characteristic ways of operation. One of these ways are the service concepts branded around some core demand or competence, which conduct RDI in co-operation with small and medium enterprises (SME) utilizing applied and practical methods. Their purpose is to aid commercial actors with their industry-recognized problems to grow regional competitiveness.
This research aims to understand how these applied RDI service concepts work socio-technically, and to examine their role in their respective UAS and more broadly in different systems of innovation. The research adopts a social constructivist views of technical innovation to explain the inner workings of these RDI organizations in relation to relevant innovation systems. Main theoretical backgrounds and lenses are those of actor-network theory (ANT) and systems of innovation (SI).
The research is a case study with an ethnographic nature, based on ANT, avoiding purely social or technological explanations. The study utilizes traditional qualitative methods associated with ethnographies. The case to be studied are the service concepts of TEQU and Frostbit in Lapland UAS. The deliverable result is a rich description about networks, interactions and translations in and with these technologically oriented RDI organizations and the identified innovation systems. These objectives can be valued as societal, as the UASâs RDI role in the national innovation system is in motion. Innovation systems can be seen as complex networks of actors and institutions that interact to create, facilitate and disseminate knowledge. The impacts pursued with this study are to evoke discussion in both theoretical and societal dimensions. Theoretical discussions this research contributes are innovation management and diffusion of innovations. Societal discussion it partakes in is innovation policy and the role of UASâs in innovation systems in Finland. Premise underpinning the research: The project is a continuum of previous research done about Finnish UASs, RDI and innovation systems. Researchâs premise is that the Finnish UASs ways of practicing RDI with SME-oriented service concepts enacts innovation systems. It's also assumed that instead of purely technological or academic work they construct solution-oriented socio-technical ensembles that differ from the more traditionally held linear innovation models. Research questions: in the context of public-private RDI-activities performed by the Lapland UAS' RDI concepts in regional settings. What are the actor-networks of the RDI service concepts? What do they consist of and how are they formed and maintained? How they define goals and what leads to their perceived success or failure? What are the key characteristics that enable or constrain their innovation processes? How do they relate to some perceived "innovation systems"? Do the RDI-activities enact innovation systems? What is their role in regional competitiveness? What kinds of models of innovation do they hold?
See attached Toulmin Argument. Expected research results: The aim and objective of this project is to create an ANT and SI inspired rich socio-technical ethnographic description about these kinds of service concepts (case studies: TEQU & Frostbit of Lapland UAS) in relation to and their roles in systems of innovation. Work plan and schedule: The project is to be done as a part-time research, working full-time with the Lapland UAS.
See attached link to the Gantt-chart. Research data and methods: Observation notes, interviews, surveys and public & internal documents. The rich description is constructed with qualitative ethnographic methods, utilizing an actor-network theory -type of framework. The data to form this description is collected with participative and non-participative observations, interviews and surveys. Document analysis is also used to aid and supplement the qualitative interpretation. No codified preliminary data, but a six-year working experience about the RDI service concepts in question, which hastens the formal observatory methodsâ implementation. Short comparative or enriching inquiries about The Research Institute of Measuring and Modelling for the Built Environment (MeMo) and Jamk University of Applied Sciences are also possible. Informed consent is gathered from the participants, and their right and ways to modify or withdraw that consent is informed and ensured. Data considering any participants/subjects is anonymized and handled according to good practices on the type of data in question. Monograph: A body of texts will be produced in hypertext/markdown format in Obisidian environment. Interlinked body of hypertext builds a type of a "Wiki" or "pattern language" about the research. The monograph will be compiled mainly from these texts. Risk assessment: Main risk for implementation is the possible delay of the project due to part-time research. The research is thus designed to have as little timing-sensitive parts as possible, to enable flexible and resilient implementation. No ethical issues or ethical reviews foreseen. Self- and faculty monitoring practiced. Scientific: The scientific impact pursued with this research is to âopen the black boxâ of RDI in Finnish UASs in regional systems of innovation. It aims to renew the discussion about technically oriented RDI work in these types of institutions and their stakeholders, with not purely technological or social reasons, but taking to account them both. According to bibliometric searches there is little research about these types of organizations in frameworks of ANT and management, but the project is not novel as an ANT or STS study and no special potential for scientific breakthroughs is expected. Open science: Open-access wide-audience publication (publ. type E/D) at the start/mid phase of the project to market the project and promote societal discussion. Lapland University Consortium open-access channels are preferred, in Finnish. One publication in wider-audience professional or scientific publication (publ. type D/B). Open-access publications considering Universities of Applied Sciences are preferred, joint publication with stakeholders or academic partners favored, in Finnish or English. Open-access publishing of Obsidian library/vault as a "digital garden", to communicate the research "in the making". Beyond academia: Discussion with Universities of Applied Sciences, Regional Councils and other RDI funders, SME's and RDI policy makers are promoted.

research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.title: Toulmin Argument
research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.description:
Last updated
3.3.2025
Grounds
Empirical observations reveal a network of heterogenous actors working in a setting that aims for the development of regional competitiveness by the means of innovation.
And sinceWarrant
The flux of these actions constitutes as the practical enactment and materialization of social reality.
On account ofBacking
Actor-network theory (and after) and innovation system studies.
And becauseQualifier
These grounds can be seen as a description of the social reality of innovation systems.
SoClaim
Finnish UAS's RDI concepts actively contribute to the construction and realization of different innovation systems.
UnlessRebuttal
We deny this type of description having explanatory power over the social reality.

zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.title: @bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023
zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.description: Cite Bignetti, B., De Souza, A. C. A. A., & Petrini, M. (2023). Actor-network theory: Methodological issues in practice. Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal, 18(2), 142â162. https://doi.org/10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Bignetti, Bernardo Author:: De Souza, Ana Clara Aparecida Alves Author:: Petrini, Maira ~ Title:: Actor-network theory: methodological issues in practice Year:: 2023 Citekey:: bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal Volume:: 18 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 142-162 DOI:: 10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Link . Abstract Purpose This study demonstrates a practical use of Actor-Network Theory (ANT), showing methodological, predictive and unforeseen issues that emerged during the data collection and analysis phases and how they were addressed during the development of this research. Design/methodology/approach Based on the research of reapplication of a âtecnologia socialâ (TS) of entrepreneurial education, this article explores the authorâs reflections on the adoption of ANT as a theoretical-methodological approach, highlighting the practical implications of a social material theory during fieldwork. Findings The adoption of ANT places the researcher in front of methodological issues not always foreseen in the research design. Four moments to a practical path through the engagement of ANT agency are highlighted: the network of actors, monitoring of actors, interpretation of data collected and writing results. These moments correspond to methodological issues that the authors faced during the practical journey of the research. At each moment, the challenge aroused is discussed and the methodological choice chosen to address the issue is presented. Originality/value The engagement with ANT has enormous potential in the study of management and organizations phenomenon, but its methodological implications in practice are still challenging. The authors seek to share this investigation and engagement in ANT so that other researchers have a reference and a starting point to employ and engage in this theoretical-methodological lens. Thus, it may be possible to anticipate certain difficulties in future research designs and to glimpse at potential developments and paths that the research may lead. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@brownperpetuummo.title: @brownPerpetuumMobileSubstance1999
zotero_literaturenotes/@brownperpetuummo.description: Cite Brown, S. D., & Capdevila, R. (1999). Perpetuum Mobile: Substance, Force and the Sociology of Translation. The Sociological Review, 47(1), 26â50. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03481.x Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Brown, Steven D. Author:: Capdevila, Rose ~> FirstEditor:: Law, John Editor:: Hassard, John ~ Title:: Perpetuum Mobile : Substance, Force and the Sociology of Translation Year:: 1999 Citekey:: brownPerpetuumMobileSubstance1999 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: The Sociological Review Volume:: 47 Issue:: 1 Pages:: 26-50 DOI:: 10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03481.x Link . Abstract Going after means taking up a position with regard to something and the active pursuit of that same thing. It is the critical move par excellence, but also an act of appropriation. This essay suspends the urge to go after in preference for an exploration of the trajectory of that body of texts known as the sociology of translation. The figure of the perpetuum mobile is put into circulation through these texts in order to trace some of their more unusual and unfamiliar connections. These include a whole series of parallels with seventeenth century classical philosophy and with nineteenth century âsocial energeticsâ. Connections are drawn out by using three âtest signalsâ, which are sent on through the ANT canon: substance, force and time. Pivotal to each is the sense of how very different events and apparently diverse territories can be brought into contiguity, or folded up together. This contiguity needs to be performed rather than described, placed in translation rather than simply presented. The chapter concludes by tracing a way from the strange folds of ANT to the equally peculiar forms of early Psychology. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.title: @delaetZimbabweBushPump2000
zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.description: Cite De Laet, M., & Mol, A. (2000). The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology. Social Studies of Science, 30(2), 225â263. https://doi.org/10.1177/030631200030002002 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: De Laet, Marianne Author:: Mol, Annemarie ~ Title:: The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology Year:: 2000 Citekey:: delaetZimbabweBushPump2000 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Social Studies of Science Volume:: 30 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 225-263 DOI:: 10.1177/030631200030002002 Link . Abstract In this paper we investigate the intricacies of an admirable water pumping device - the Zimbabwe Bush Pump B' type - so as to find out what makes it an appropriate technology'. This turns out to be what we call the fluidity' of the pump (of its boundaries, or of its working order, and of its maker). We find that in travelling to intractable places, an object that isn't too rigorously bounded, that doesn't impose itself but tries to serve, that is adaptable, flexible and responsive - in short, a fluid object - may well prove to be stronger than one which is firm. By analyzing the success and failure of this device, its agency and the way in which it shapes new configurations in the Zimbabwean socio-technical landscape, we partake in the current move in science and technology studies to transform what it means to be an actor. And by mobilizing the term love for articulating our relation to the Bush Pump, we try to contribute to shaping novel ways of doing' normativity. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@kampactornetwork.title: @kampActorNetworkTheory2019
zotero_literaturenotes/@kampactornetwork.description: Cite Kamp, A. (2019). ActorâNetwork Theory. Teoksessa A. Kamp, Oxford Research Encyclopedia of Education. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/acrefore/9780190264093.013.526 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstBookauthor:: Kamp, Annelies ~> FirstAuthor:: Kamp, Annelies ~ Title:: ActorâNetwork Theory Year:: 2019 Citekey:: kampActorNetworkTheory2019 itemType:: bookSection Book:: Publisher:: Oxford University Press ISBN:: 978-0-19-026409-3 Link . Abstract Actorânetwork theory (ANT) is an approach to research that sits with a broader body of new materialism; a body of work that displaces humanism to consider dynamic assemblages of humans and nonhumans. Originally developed in the social studies of science and technology undertaken in the second half of the 20th century, ANT has increasingly been taken up in other arenas of social inquiry. Researchers working with ANT do not accept the unquestioned use of âsocialâ explanations for educational phenomena. Rather, the social, like all other effects, is taken to be an enactment of heterogenous assemblages of human and nonhuman entities. The role of the educational researcher is to trace these processes of assemblage and reassemblage, foregrounding the ways in which certain entities establish sufficient allies to assume some degree of ârealnessâ in the world. Aligning most closely with ethnographic orientations, ANT does not outline a method. However, it could be argued that a number of propositions are shared in ANT-inspired approaches: first, that the world is made up of actors/actants, all of which are ontologically symmetrical. Humans are not privileged in ANT. Second, the principle of irreductionâthere is no essence within or beyond any process of assemblage. Actors are concrete; there is no âpotentialâ other than their actions in the moment. Entities are nothing more than an effect of assemblage. Third, the concept of translation and its processes of mediation that transform objects when they encounter one another. Finally, the principle of alliance. Actants gain strength only through their alliances. These propositions have specific implications for data generation, analysis, and reporting. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@lawantcomplexity.description: Cite Law, J. (1999). After Ant: Complexity, Naming and Topology. The Sociological Review, 47(1), 1â14. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03479.x Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Law, John ~> FirstEditor:: Hassard, John Editor:: Law, John ~ Title:: After Ant: Complexity, Naming and Topology Year:: 1999 Citekey:: lawAntComplexityNaming1999 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: The Sociological Review Volume:: 47 Issue:: 1 Pages:: 1-14 DOI:: 10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03479.x Link . Abstract What is a theory? Or, more broadly, what is a good way of addressing intellectual problems? This paper explores the tension central to the notion of an âactorâ - ânetworkâ which is an intentionally oxymoronic term that combinesâand elides the distinction betweenâstructure and agency. It then notes that this tension has been lost as âactor-networkâ has been converted into a smooth and consistent âtheoryâ that has been (too) simply and easily displaced, criticised or applied. It recalls another term important to the actor-network approachâthat of translationâ which is another term in tension, since (the play of words works best in the romance languages) to translate is to also betray ( traductore, tradition). It is suggested that in social theory simplicity should not displace the complexities of tension. The chapter concludes by exploring a series of metaphors for grappling with tensions rather than wishing these away, and in particular considers the importance of topological complexity, and the notion of fractionality. Today we have naming of parts. Yesterday, We had daily cleaning. And tomorrow morning, We shall have what to do after firing. But today, Today we have naming of parts. Japonica Glistens like coral in all of the neighbouring gardens, And today we have naming of parts.' (Henry Reed, Lessons of the War: 1) . .

Cite Nimmo, R. (2011). Actor-Network Theory and Methodology: Social Research in a More-Than-Human World. Methodological Innovations Online, 6(3), 108â119. https://doi.org/10.4256/mio.2011.010 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Nimmo, Richie ~ Title:: Actor-Network Theory and Methodology: Social Research in a More-Than-Human World Year:: 2011 Citekey:: nimmoActorNetworkTheoryMethodology2011 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Methodological Innovations Online Volume:: 6 Issue:: 3 Pages:: 108-119 DOI:: 10.4256/mio.2011.010
Link Kokoteksti. Abstract This article explores the methodological implications of actor-network theory for social research. Pointing to an increasing awareness of ANT in sociological discourse, but assuming that it is more widely known than well understood, the article outlines some of the key features of ANT as an approach to social life, before addressing the tricky question of how these ideas translate into methodological practice. The possibilities of the approach are illustrated by reference to the author's own ANT-inspired historical research on the socio-material history of dairy milk in the UK, which is used as a point of reference and an example throughout. Particular attention is given to the practical method deployed in the milk study, namely documentary historiography, leading to a critical exploration of the use of ANT in the analysis of historical texts. This involves considering the nature of the relationship between texts and lived practices, and drawing out how ANT offers a distinctive way of seeing texts which challenges the standard ethnographic view of texts and fundamentally transforms the issue. Given that documentary historiography is not a method strongly associated with actor-network theory because it raises considerable methodological dilemmas, this provides one particular account of how such dilemmas can be managed or overcome. Social researchers interested in the potential of actor-network theory should be able to draw upon this in exploring the possibilities of the approach for their own work. . .

index.html.title: Index
index.html.description:
This website is for publishing my part-time research project while it happens. During the research i build a body of texts in a format of hypertext, with a simple markup language (fin. merkintÃ¤kieli) called Markdown. What that means, is that these texts link into each other constituting a non-linear repository where the contents relate to each other. For a taste of this you can jump straight into the Actor-Network Theory note, my Research Plan or see examples of similar (or way fancier) implementations in the Digital Garden note.
All of this is managed in a personal knowledge base system called Obsidian. This repository in Obsidian is called a Vault. When it's published, it can be described with terms such as Digital Garden or Wiki (without the possibility for reader editing). This site has been translated straight from my Obsidian Vault into a www-publishable HTML with Nathan George's HTML Export Plugin. It is then hosted in and published with GitHub and it's Pages functionality.Info This is very much a work in progress. The maturity of the content lives and that's kinda the whole point of it. Not a single note is permanent, fixed or "ready". Also not everything in my Vault will be published right away. This site itself is a static epoch of my Vault and has to be manually updated into the web whenever wanted to. The project has started: 1.1.2025 This site has launched: 7.3.2025 Last web update: 13.6.2025 Word count: 7506 Page count: ~25 Currently working on: Literature survey (mainly ANT & innovation), for Framework design Methods design Caution The functionalities of this website are not perfect. Translating from Obsidian flavoured Markdown to HTML (with all the third-party plugins that i use) does not mirror my Vault perfectly. I focus on content, but will gladly hear of any hiccups in the user interface. Main problems are: Citations using Pandoc citation keys have their technical restrictions and might not be presented in the most conventional or human-readable format. Site's layout has it's quirks, for example mobile device accessibility is not good and listings may have unnecessary line breaks.
Schedules written in Markwhen do not work in web view. Contact The purpose of this site is to promote open science, -source and -access, so i welcome any comments, questions, suggestions etc. from all grounds. Janne W. literature-survey/framework/innovation/i.title: Innovation System
literature-survey/framework/innovation/i.description:
Innovation Systems is a concept in understanding how new, economically useful knowledge is produced, diffused, and utilized within an economy. This concept moves beyond viewing innovation as isolated events, emphasizing it as an ongoing, ubiquitous, and cumulative process that is deeply rooted to learning in the economic structure and institutional setup. (Lundvall, 1992)(Johnson, 1992). The term is considered a concept rather than a general theory, though it is built upon a series of coherent assumptions derived from systematic empirical work (Lundvall, 2010b)...
Innovation systems can be understood in a narrow sense, which includes organizations directly involved in research and exploration like R&D departments, technological institutes, and universities. In a broad sense, it includes all parts and aspects of the economic structure and institutional setup that affect learning, searching, and exploring, such as the production system, marketing system, and financial system. A National System of Innovation (NSI) specifically encompasses these elements and relationships located within or rooted inside the borders of a nation-state. (Freeman, 1992);(Lundvall, 1992).
Key concepts of National Systems of Innovation in (Lundvall, 2010a) Institutions: formal organizations like firms, universities, government agencies and informal norms, routines, and rules that shape interactions.
Learning: innovation is fundamentally a learning process that occurs through interactions between actors in the system. Interactions and Networks: relations between participants will be influenced by the specific characteristics of the partners in a number of dimensions.
Differentiation of Innovation: The traditional, broad term is differentiated to distinguish between "incremental innovations" and "radical innovations".
Development Blocks: drawing on DahmÃ©n's idea, refers to interconnected sequences of innovations and investments in related sectors that form a dynamic process of economic development.
The term has been introduced from research into politics. In politics and policy it has been recognized to work as a loose border object rather than well defined and explanatory scientific term, in a similar way that Porters ideas have been used in policymaking. Despite attempts in "mainstream" and "non-mainstream" economics (Dalum, 1992);(Fagerberg, 1992), it seems that innovation systems cannot be quantitatively compared in a fruitful way: they have to be situated and can't be generalized very well. This makes case studies an important way to gain understanding of innovation systems. (Miettinen, 2002)....

literature-survey/framework/innovation/m.title: Model of Interessement
literature-survey/framework/innovation/m.description:
The "model of interessement" or translation model is based on the process of translation as @akrichKeySuccessInnovation2002 it describes, tries to provide a richer understanding of how innovations travel and transform the socio-material worlds. In ANT it is contrasted with the Model of Diffusion. It does this by focusing on the dynamic processes of network construction, the active roles of diverse actors, and the ongoing negotiations and transformations that shape their trajectories. It moves beyond a simple linear model of spread to examine the complex web of relationships and actions that constitute innovation in practice. @akrichKeySuccessInnovation2002a;@akrichKeySuccessInnovation2002.
The model of interessement is based upon the principles of agnosticism, generalized symmetry and relies on the concept of translation @akrichKeySuccessInnovation2002a;@callonElementsSociologyTranslation1986. It suggests that innovation is a process, not a fixed result, highlighting the precarious and uncertain nature of network stabilization. The most significant difference is that the interessement/translation model focuses on the continuous, costly, and precarious work required to make things hold together and move, whereas the diffusion model assumes an inherent, effortless spread unless resisted.In the translation model, the analyst does not impose pre-given categories but rather follows the actors themselves, allowing their perspectives and practices to shape the account. This approach is descriptive, aiming to account for how order is produced from disorder, rather than assuming it. ...

literature-survey/methodology/controvers.title: Controversies
literature-survey/methodology/controvers.description:
Controversies can be used as a tool to see and understand how the sociotechnical world is formed and transformed. They are not merely disagreements to be resolved, but rather dynamic situations where actors disagree and where established realities are put into question. A controversy refers to any aspect of science and technology that is not yet stabilized, closed, or "black boxed", representing shared uncertainty. (Venturini, 2010)(Bignetti et al., 2023)....
Controversies are situations where actors discover they cannot ignore each other, leading to a negotiation. They are not necessarily "formal" negotiations and discussions between human actors, but point to any type of conflicts that decide, and are decided by, the distribution of power. They tend to be complex and reduction-resistant phenomena, meaning they cannot be reduced to a single question or simple answers, as actors often disagree even on the very questions to be asked. (Latour, 1987),Part A.)(Venturini, 2010)
In ANT methodologies, translations & controversies are considered one of the best available occasions to observe the social world and its making, revealing how collective existence is constructed through collective work (Venturini, 2010). They explicitly advocate for studying science and technology "in action" and following controversies under the lids of "black boxes", because these disputes provide the analyst with an essential resource to render social connections traceable (Latour, 2005),Part I).
Rather than imposing predefined categories, ANT allows actors to deploy the full range of controversies in which they are immersed, enabling a better grasp of how the social is generated. Controversies are critical sites where "ontological politics" unfolds, highlighting how realities are enacted, shaped, and contested, and how things could always be "otherwise". (Latour, 2005),Part I). They allow ANT to question conventional politics by foregrounding the denial of singularity and the championing of multiplicity surrounding existence (Alcadipani & Hassard, 2010)p.424-425). The focus shifts from "matters of fact" to "matters of concern" in controversies, viewing disputed issues as interesting "gatherings" rather than stable objects (Latour, 2005)p.114)....
(Venturini, 2010) and (Walsham, 1997), after (Latour, 1996) describe studying controversies with ANT as "thorny and intricate" and making investigation "slower and harder," often producing a "mass of detail" that is difficult to manage and represent. Representing the dynamic, "magmatic movement" of controversies, where actors and networks constantly liquefy and solidify, is challenging. Some have also pointed out the difficulty of authentically representing the "voices of nonhumans" in ANT accounts, as they are always mediated through human categories, or reducing people to the status of things (Jackson, 2015).
ANT has faced criticism for appearing to lack substantive political critique or having an "amoral posture," even being accused of "conniving with those in power". However, proponents argue that ANT does bring politics back in, by focusing on how realities are enacted and contested, and on the consequences of inclusions and exclusions. (Alcadipani & Hassard, 2010).

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Immutable Mobile
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description: Immutable mobile is a concept referring to an entity or object that is both stable and transportable, meaning it holds its shape or identity while moving across time and space. It appears as a stable, fixed, and unified entity because of its punctualisation, allowing others to disregard its underlying complexities and assumptions. (Latour & Woolgar, 1986). A good example presented by (Walsham, 1997)p.469-470) of an immutable mobile, is the idea of "software as frozen discource"; an inscription which resists change and displays properties of irreversibility. On the contrary the well known study of the Zimbabwe Bush Pump by (De Laet & Mol, 2000) exhibits a mutable mobile, where the pump undergoes transformations and adaptations while traveling.Knowledge production and mediation Network formation and stability/maintenance Power and control at a distance ...

literature-survey/framework/innovation/l.title: Learning
literature-survey/framework/innovation/l.description:
In the context of innovation systems research, (Lundvall, 2010) portrays learning as a multifaceted and crucial process that is fundamental to innovation, competence building, and economic and societal development. It is not merely an individual cognitive activity but is deeply embedded in social, organizational, and institutional contexts (Lundvall, 1992)p.1-2). Learning is considered the most fundamental resource and process in the modern economy, which heads the term of "the learning economy" (Lundvall, 2016).
Standard neoclassical economic theory is built on the concept of scarcity, focusing on the allocation of a given set of scarce resources. It tends to view technology and innovation as an exogenous process or external variable that falls equally on all perfectly rational and completely informed actors, rather than something emerging from within the economic system (Pansera et al., 2025). The learning economy perspective posits that knowledge is the most fundamental resource, and learning is the most important process. It focuses on the creation of new kinds of resources, new use values and the capability of an economy to produce and diffuse "use values" with new characteristics. (Lundvall, 2010)
Bengt-Ãke Lundvall While standard economics tends to regard optimality in the allocation of a given set of use values as the economic problem, par preference, we shall focus on the capability of an economy to produce and diffuse use values with new characteristics. Moreover, while standard economics takes an atomistic view of the economy, we shall focus on the systemic interdependence between formally independent economic subjects. (Lundvall, 2016)p.62). Rationality/uncertainty Social activity Process/Outcome ... Types of learning Searching/Exploring ...

literature-survey/framework/innovation/m.title: Model of Diffusion
literature-survey/framework/innovation/m.description:
The "model of diffusion" is a concept criticized by ANT for its simplified and often misleading representation of how facts, ideas, and technologies spread or fail to spread. In @latourScienceActionHow1987Part C.) the model of diffusion is contrasted with the Model of Interessement or translation. In the model of diffusion, facts and artefacts are endowed with their own inherent inertia, meaning they seemingly move and spread by themselves, even without the active involvement of actors. This invents a form of determinism, suggesting that the behavior of actors is caused by the diffusion of facts and machines, rather than acknowledging the active roles of human and non-human actors in shaping them.
Other arguments and examples that @latourScienceActionHow1987Part C.) makes, are that novelty is explained as the result of "discovery" by some "great initiators" or "geniuses" (e.g., Diesel, Pasteur, Curie) who help pre-existing entities (like microbes or engines) appear in public, rather than recognizing the continuous shaping and transformation by many actors. When facts or innovations fail to spread, the diffusion model explains this by stating that "some groups resist" due to e.g. vested interests, ignorance or even stupidity. These social groups are seen as passive mediums that slow down or absorb the impact of ideas, rather than actively co-producing or transforming them.
ANT scholars argue that the diffusion model is absurd because it ignores the active involvement of a multitude of actors in the making and spreading of scientific facts and technologies. Instead, ANT emphasizes that effects like agency and power are collectively generated within heterogeneous networks of diverse human and non-human actors. @latourPasteurizationFrance1988;@latourScienceActionHow1987;@akrichKeySuccessInnovation2002a.

literature-survey/framework/innovation/d.title: Development Blocks
literature-survey/framework/innovation/d.description:
Development blocks is a concept in the economic theory of Erik DahmÃ©n. It is used to understand sequences of evolutionary steps in innovation and economic development, particularly how radical innovations create a basis for further adaptive and induced innovations, or to analyze industrial transformation, particularly in the context of business cycles (Andersen, 2010).
An innovation can be seen as creating the foundation for a series of more or less adaptive decisions and activities over time. This framework combines a Schumpeterian "push" (from radical innovation) with a Schmooklerian "pull" (induced innovations and demand) (Andersen, 2010)p.90). A core innovation introduces a "jump in the degree of disequilibrium", initiating a sequence of structural tensions and their partial resolution. These tensions often manifest as price and cost signals in various markets, asking for a "gap filling" to address revealed needs or problems in the related chains of production and use, which are also seen as innovative and risky endeavors. (Andersen, 2010).From these key insights we can conceive the following ordering:Note At the core of a development block analysis is an particular innovation or a cluster of innovations. These innovations create new dependencies and relationships between different parts of the economy, such as new firms, new technologies, and new production processes. As a new innovation takes hold, it often creates imbalances and bottlenecks in other parts of the economy. These structural tensions create pressure for further investment and development to "catch up". The "gap filling" that results from this pressure is what drives the transformation process. Once the complementarities are fully established and the structural tensions are resolved, the block loses its potential for driving further rapid growth. ... Networky nature Process Electricity as an example

zotero_literaturenotes/@venturinibuildin.title: @venturiniBuildingFaultsHow2012
zotero_literaturenotes/@venturinibuildin.description:
Cite Venturini, T. (2012). Building on faults: How to represent controversies with digital methods. Public Understanding of Science, 21(7), 796â812. https://doi.org/10.1177/0963662510387558 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Venturini, Tommaso ~ Title:: Building on faults: How to represent controversies with digital methods Year:: 2012 Citekey:: venturiniBuildingFaultsHow2012 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Public Understanding of Science Volume:: 21 Issue:: 7 Pages:: 796-812 DOI:: 10.1177/0963662510387558
Link LÃ¤hetetty versio. Abstract In a previous article in this journal, I introduced Bruno Latourâs cartography of controversies and I discussed half of it, namely how to observe techno-scientific controversies. In this article I will concentrate on the remaining half: how to represent the complexity of social debates in a legible form. In my previous paper, we learnt how to explore the richness of collective existence through Actor-Network Theory. In this one, I will discuss how to render such complexity through an original visualization device: the controversy-website. Capitalizing on the potential of digital technologies, the controversy-website has been developed as a multilayered toolkit to trace and aggregate information on public debates. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@venturinidivingm.title: @venturiniDivingMagmaHow2010
zotero_literaturenotes/@venturinidivingm.description:
Cite Venturini, T. (2010). Diving in magma: How to explore controversies with actor-network theory. Public Understanding of Science, 19(3), 258â273. https://doi.org/10.1177/0963662509102694 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Venturini, Tommaso ~ Title:: Diving in magma: how to explore controversies with actor-network theory Year:: 2010 Citekey:: venturiniDivingMagmaHow2010 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Public Understanding of Science Volume:: 19 Issue:: 3 Pages:: 258-273 DOI:: 10.1177/0963662509102694
Link LÃ¤hetetty versio. Abstract The cartography of controversies is a set of techniques to explore and visualize issues. It was developed by Bruno Latour as a didactic version of Actor-Network Theory to train college students in the investigation of contemporary socio-technical debate. The scope and interest of such cartography, however, exceed its didactic origin. Adopted and developed in several universities in Europe and the US, the cartography of controversies is today a full research method, though, unfortunately, not a much documented one. To fill this lack of documentation, we draw on our experience as Latourâs teaching assistant, to introduce some of the main techniques of the social cartographer toolkit. In particular, in these pages we will focus on exploration, leaving the discussion of visualization tools to a further paper. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@alcadipaniactorn.title: @alcadipaniActorNetworkTheoryOrganizations2010
zotero_literaturenotes/@alcadipaniactorn.description: Cite Alcadipani, R., & Hassard, J. (2010). Actor-Network Theory, organizations and critique: Towards a politics of organizing. Organization, 17(4), 419â435. https://doi.org/10.1177/1350508410364441 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Alcadipani, Rafael Author:: Hassard, John ~ Title:: Actor-Network Theory, organizations and critique: towards a politics of organizing Year:: 2010 Citekey:: alcadipaniActorNetworkTheoryOrganizations2010 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Organization Volume:: 17 Issue:: 4 Pages:: 419-435 DOI:: 10.1177/1350508410364441 Link . Abstract In recent years the approach to social theory known as Actor-Network Theory (ANT) has been adopted within a range of social science fields. Despite its popularity, ANT is considered a controversial approach in that it appears to promote a sociological perspective that lacks substantive political critique. This is argued to be particularly true in ANTâs âtranslationsâ in management and organization studies (MOS). In this article, we argue that the âANT and Afterâ literature offers the potential to develop such a political critique. In particular we suggest it presents the opportunity to develop an approach that de-naturalizes organization(s), has the ability to deliver critical performativity, and at the same time offer a reflexive approach to management and organizational knowledge. Using organizational examples, we argue that ANT and After can offer insights relevant to the development of a critical perspective on MOS, notably through its advocacy of a âpolitical ontologyâ of organizing. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@chaminadeadvance.description:
Cite
Chaminade, C., Lundvall, B.-Ã., & Haneef, S. (2018). Advanced introduction to national innovation systems. Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd.
Synth
Contribution:: Related:: Md
FirstAuthor:: Chaminade, Cristina
Author:: Lundvall, Bengt-Ãke
Author:: Haneef, Shagufta
~
Title:: Advanced introduction to national innovation systems
Year:: 2018
Citekey:: chaminadeAdvancedIntroductionNational2018
itemType:: book
Publisher:: Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd.
Location:: Cheltenham, GLOS
ISBN:: 978-1-78536-203-3 Link
.
Abstract
"Innovation studies is an evolving interdisciplinary field that has moved away from the weaknesses of neoclassical thinking and embraced evolutionary theory. In this timely book, the authors offer a precise introduction to the nature of national innovation systems (NIS), examining the history of the concept and its use in todays world.This book uses language appropriate for both social science and engineering scholars to offer an accurate synopsis of the emergence of the concept, its theoretical core and its evolution. It analyses both developed and developing countries in terms of their NIS and its application to current societal challenges, such as economic growth, inclusive development and environmental sustainability, in an increasingly globalized and interconnected world. Key features include:.Three authors from three different generations and countries offer an overview of NIS from around the world. Extensive use of examples from the Global North and Global South. Recommended in-depth reading after each topical chapter. Overview of future research challengesâ¢up-to-date review of the literature and engagement in current debates.Erudite and accessible, this unique book on NIS can easily be used for undergraduate and graduate teaching. It is a valuable, and much-needed resource for teachers, students and researchers at all levels."--Publisher's description
. .

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
